questions.question: Which framework can automatically populate values for the Priority and Category fields based on the Short description field value?

comments.content: Predictive Intelligence uses machine learning algorithms to set field values during record creation.
A its the correct opton, predictive intelligence do that on fields.

Correct answer is A:
The Predictive Intelligence classification framework enables you to use machine-learning algorithms to set field values during record creation, such as setting the incident category based on the short description.

Correct answer is A.
 For example, when an incident is created, ServiceNow will automatically assign the correct category, priority and assignment group based on the record's short description. 
Assignment rules: The instance can automatically assign a task to a user or group based on pre-defined conditions by using data lookup rules and assignment rules.

questions.question: A new employee joins the IT department and needs to perform work assigned to Network and Hardware groups. How would you set up their access? (Choose three.)
answers: A. Add User Account to Hardware group
B. Add User Account to IT Knowledgebase
D. Add User Account to itil group
E. Add User Account to Network group
F. Add User Account to ACL

comments.content:
C - NEW employee will need an account setting up otherwise they can't access anything ever. If your work Instance use LDAP or Azure Sync or some other method then good for you but these are not configured OOB and the question doesn't reference them. Either way, the very first step is account setup regardless of means.
AE - best practice is to assign Role(s) to the Group (especially for dependencies) so ITIL should have been added to these already therefore adding the new user to either Group will allow them to inherit ITIL Role.

Creating a Group specifically to assign the ITIL Role would not be best practice as it could be removed independently of other access that requires it to be in place. This means that adding to an ITIL Group would be incorrect (as would adding the Role directly).
replies:
P.S.
AE - This is also after glossing over the simple fact that they need to be part of the Groups to access those assignments.

comments.content:
ADE is the answer. 
 I never create user accounts in SN. They are always sent vis feed through LDAP. 
The question is about access, and with an ITIL role, this user can't see anything. The question is poorly worded.
replies: Even if you don't create them manually, the first step is to have the account. The ITIL role should not be given as is, but as part of a group. HW and NTW groups should have that role and he would get it by being added there. ACE is correct.

comments.content:
darsy2001 is right. ITIL is a role

https://docs.servicenow.com/bundle/utah-platform-administration/page/administer/roles/reference/r_BaseSystemRoles.html

replies: NEW employee needs access, they can't access anything without an account.

comments.content: Hardware gp, Network gp is correct but with Itil > it is a role also user already has an account so creating user account doesn't make no sense.

A. Add User Account to Hardware group - CORRECT
B. Add User Account to IT Knowledgebase - NOT RELATED
C. Create User Account - NOT RELATED - Questions is about access. Also, in most cases account will be created through a feed such as AD/LDAP but most often groups need to be manually added, either in ServiceNow or AD
D. Add User Account to itil group - CORRECT - There can be a group with the ITIL Role
E. Add User Account to Network group - CORRECT
F. Add User Account to ACL - NOT RELATED


Correct Answer: A, D, E

replies: I agree, the question is about access....so the user account should already been created.
itil is not a group, it's a role

questions.question: What enables you to trace the connection from an infrastructure item, like a Server, to the Services that are dependent on that Server?

comments.content:
B. Relationships

ServiceNow allows you to establish relationships between different configuration items, such as servers and services. By defining relationships, you can create a map of dependencies, and this helps in understanding the impact of changes and tracing connections between various elements in your infrastructure.

comments.content: This is different then question 216. I guess if they give the option “define data source,” then that takes priority over “load data”?
Initially I opted for C, but next question #323 kind of answers this. First step is Create Import Set.
First you have to define the data source

This question is a bit tricky. If you go to the module "Load Data", you have first the option to select an existing import set or to create a new one. After that you select the "Source of the import", which could be a fiel, in this case a spreadsheet or a data source.
replies: I have to correct myself here. It asks you to select an existing table or to create a new table in the Import set table section, after you clicked on the "Load Data" module.

comments.content: The question already defines the data source that is a spreadsheet, the next step should be create import set
replies: Hi how sure are you about the answer i'm about to appear for my exam. pls reply

comments.content: Defining the data source is essential as it specifies where the data is coming from, which in this case would be the spreadsheet. This step sets the foundation for the data import process by identifying the source file or connection that will provide the data to be imported into ServiceNow.

C. Define Data Source

Defining the data source involves specifying the source from which you will be importing data. This is typically the first step before creating an Import Set or performing other import-related tasks.

questions.question: Access Control rules are applied to a specific table, like the Incident table. What is the object name for a rule that applies to the entire Incident table (all rows and fields)?

comments.content:
incident.None includes all fields and column (entire table) then comes the part where any specific field  are not to be included which is done by include.field here comes to play the incident.* (wildcard) that includes all the fields except one defined by include.field.
thus correct option will be incident.None

incident.* rule applies to all fields on the table that are NOT controlled by a specific field rule. i.e. if there are no field rules on any of the field it can represent the whole table, but as long as there's even one specific field rule it will represent all the other fields in the table but NOT this one. Hence A cannot be the correct answer.
incident.None rule represents access to the table as a whole. It's the correct answer.

Answer:  table.--None-- applies to the entire table - Pg 158 Vancouver SNAF 
Table. --*-- Represents all other fields in the table
replies: MOD don't approve... I am not 100%

comments.content:
D. incident.None
The answer is D. As seen in SNAF Page 368

questions.question: What does ServiceNow recommend as a best practice regarding data imports?
answers: A. Adjust your Transform maps, after the data is loaded into the target table.
B. Use extremely large Import Sets, instead of multiple large Import Sets.
C. Create a new Import set table for each new data load.
D. Plan time before your import to remove obsolete or inaccurate data.
E. Monitor data quality and clean imported data, using the Data Scrub Workspace.

comments.content: D - listed in the CSA book Washington as good practice
D. Ensure that your import completes successfully and that the resulting data matches your expectations.

questions.question: What contains the configuration changes made in an instance (i.e. changes in a form) and helps to implement the changes from the Dev environment to another environment?

An administrator creates “customer_table_admin” and “customer_table_user” roles for the newly created "Customer Table”. Which ACL rule would grant access to all rows and all fields to both the customer_table_admin and customer_table_user roles?

comments.content:
additional reference in ServiceNow Administrator Fundamentals eBook Page 60
The None access Control (which appears as just sys_user) granted all rows and all fields to both the table_admin and table_user roles.

Best Practice:
- when creating .* Access Controls, also create a None Access Control, because only None grants access to records
- when writing an ACL that mostly grants access, use only None
- when writing an ACL that mostly denies access, use None and .*

Completely agree with kanafuka225. The table.* is allowing access to both of these new roles to all rows and fields as specified. Conversely, table.none is restricting all row and field access to these two roles.
none will be used to grant all accesses to the record
.none is the table level which grants access to all fields and rows.

The customer .* ACL rule would grant access to all rows and all fields to both the customer_table_admin and customer_table_user roles because it uses a wildcard (*) to match any operation on the customer table. The other options are either too restrictive or too broad.
References1: Access control list rules - Product Documentation: Utah - ServiceNow4: Access Controls - ServiceNow Elite

questions.question: What are the different Notification methods that can be used to alert users when events that concern them have occurred? (Choose three.)

comments.content: Email, SMS, Meeting Invitation is the correct answer. Check the book

Initially I selected BCE, as Meeting Invitation makes little sense as a Notification from SN. That is done via the calendar app. 

But in the book, Washington, there are 3 methods listed: Email, SMS, Meeting Invitation
I'm beginning to question the validity of the answers on this site. How in the world is a meeting invitation considered a notification???

SN Admin Fundamentals Vancouver:
pg. 324
"A notification is a tool for alerting users when events that concern them have occurred through the following methods: 

Email
SMS
Meeting Invitation
Literally read it out of the SNOW Admin knowledge book
